question: Question_02_(f)
statement:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is
true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

The curve $y=\sqrt{x}$ has no horizontal tangent lines.
sols:
Horizontal tangent lines occur when the derivative equals zero. The
derivative of \emph{y} is

$y' = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}$

However, this derivative is never zero, because for all positive values
of \emph{x} (the domain of the derivative), $y'$ will be a positive
number, not zero.

Thus $y = \sqrt{x}$ has no horizontal tangent lines, so the statement is
true.
hints:
In order for a function to have horizontal tangent lines, at some point
its derivative must be equal to zero.
